TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit Rect3D extends System.ValueType implements class System.IFormattable

Docs.summary: Represents a 3-D rectangle: for example, a cube.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Rect3D is defined as a location () and a size structure (). Because the , , and values specified for the size are magnitudes and not coordinates, they cannot be negative except in the case of an empty rectangle. An empty rectangle is specified by , which has , , and values of -Infinity. This structure is typically used to represent the bounds of a or . and Rect3D are not typically used in XAML, because no settable properties exist in the WPF 3D object model that use those types. ## XAML Text Usage

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property returns an empty <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D> whose X, Y, and Z values are positive-infinity and whose size values are negative infinity. This is the only situation in which size values can be negative.

Docs.value: <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Point3D"> that represents the origin of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D>, typically the back bottom left corner. The default value is (0,0,0).

remarks.format: ## Remarks Note that in the 3-D coordinate system, the positive Y axis points up (assuming that the camera's property is positive). Therefore, this property usually represents the back bottom left corner of the in the scene. is typically used to represent the bounds of a or . and are not typically used in XAML, because no settable properties exist in the WPF 3D object model that use those types. ## XAML Text Usage

.method public hidebysig instance void Offset(valuetype System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Vector3D offsetVector) cil managed

Docs.summary: Sets the offset translation of the <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D"> to the provided value, specified as a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Vector3D>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D> is typically used to represent the bounds of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.MeshGeometry3D> or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Model3D>.
Note that calling the Offset method will only have an effect if you can change the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D.Y%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D.Z%2A> properties directly. Because <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D> is a value type, if you reference a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D> object by using a property or indexer, you get a copy of the object, not a reference to the object. If you attempt to change <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D.X%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D.Y%2A>, or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D.Z%2A> on a property or indexer reference, a compiler error occurs. Similarly, calling Offset on the property or indexer will not change the underlying object. If you want to change the value of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D> that is referenced as a property or indexer, create a new <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D>, modify its fields, and then assign the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Rect3D> back to the property or indexer.
